{{nowrap|''[[Celebrity Big Brother 10]]''}} | signature = | website = {{url|http://julianclary.co.uk}} }} '''Julian Peter McDonald Clary''' (born 25 May 1959) is an English comedian, actor, presenter and novelist. Openly gay, Clary began appearing on television in the mid-1980s and became known for his deliberately stereotypical [[camp (style)|camp]] style. Since then he has also acted in films, television and stage productions, and was the winner of ''[[Celebrity Big Brother 10]]'' in 2012. ==Early life and education== Clary was born in [[Surbiton]], Surrey, to Brenda (née McDonald), a probation officer, and Peter J. Clary, a policeman. He was brought up in [[Teddington]] with two older sisters. By his own account, he was conceived "in broad daylight" in [[Clacton-on-Sea]] in 1958. Two of his great-grandparents were Germans who immigrated to Britain at the end of the 19th century.{{cite web|title=WDYTYA? Series Two: Celebrity Gallery|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/familyhistory/get_started/wdytya_s2_celeb_gallery_04.shtml|publisher=BBC|accessdate=7 June 2014}} He was raised a Catholic.{{cite news|url=http://tvnz.co.nz/close-up/talks-camp-comedian-julian-clary-3474405|title=Close Up talks to camp comedian Julian Clary|publisher=tvnz.co.nz|date= |accessdate=12 May 2010}}:(Commentary; ''"The conservatively raised Catholic with the flawless skin is now happy to confront aging and he is taking it literally in his stride."'') He later studied English and drama at [[Goldsmiths, University of London|Goldsmiths' College, University of London]]. ==Career== ===Stand-up comedy=== Clary began his career under the name Leo Hurll, a fake keyboardist for pop band Thinkman (a recording project conceived by [[Rupert Hine]]).{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wkBLM_C4iIA |title=visible in the video for the song "Formula" |publisher=YouTube.com |date= |accessdate=7 June 2014}}Julian Clary confirms this in his autobiography, ''A young man's passage''. He entered the [[alternative comedy]] scene in the early 1980s, first under the alias "Gillian Pieface", and later as "The Joan Collins Fanclub". He wore heavy [[glamour (presentation)|glam]] make-up and dressed in outrageous clothes, often involving leather/PVC and hinting at [[Bondage (BDSM)|bondage]]. His pet dog "Fanny the Wonder Dog", a [[whippet]], also featured in performances. Since then, Clary has undertaken several successful tours of his stage act, four of which have been released on home video, including ''The Mincing Machine Tour'' (1989), ''My Glittering Passage'' (1993), ''Lord of the Mince'' (2011), and ''Position Vacant: Apply Within'', which ran throughout the autumn of 2012 and between April and June 2013. In April 2014 he took the show to Australia and New Zealand.{{cite web|url=http://julianclary.co.uk/positionvacantapplywithin.html#promo |title=Julian Clary's Official Website |publisher=Julianclary.co.uk |date=27 April 2014 |accessdate=7 June 2014}} Clary's latest tour, ''The Joy of Mincing'', toured the UK throughout 2016.{{cite web|title=Julian Clary on Twitter|url=https://twitter.com/julianclary/status/640482147934052353|website=www.twitter.com|accessdate=14 November 2015}} He was named as the Ambassador for the 2016 [[Adelaide Fringe Festival|Adelaide Fringe comedy festival]], responsible for promoting the festival internationally.{{cite web|title=British comic Julian Clary named 2016 Fringe ambassador|url=https://www.adelaidefringe.com.au/news/british-comic-julian-clary-named-2016-fringe-ambassador|website=www.adelaidefringe.com.au|accessdate=14 November 2015}} ===Television=== After a number of appearances on ''[[Saturday Live (UK TV series)|Friday Night Live]]'' in the mid-late 1980s,{{cite news|title=Interview: Julian Clary, comedian|url=http://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/interview-julian-clary-comedian-1-832933|accessdate=14 November 2015|work=The Scotsman|date=9 November 2010}} Clary co-hosted the short-lived [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] game show ''Trick or Treat'' in 1989 with [[Mike Smith (television presenter)|Mike Smith]], before achieving greater success later that year with his own high-camp [[Channel 4]] gameshow, ''[[Sticky Moments with Julian Clary]]''.{{cite news|last1=Millard|first1=Rosie|title=Sticky Moments|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/sticky-moments-1584972.html|accessdate=14 November 2015|work=The Independent|date=23 October 2011}} More a vehicle for his brand of humour than a genuine gameshow, ''Sticky Moments'' was a light-hearted "non-quiz" satire, with him often awarding points because he liked the contestants, rather than because they possessed a particular skill or aptitude. He later starred in the 1992 audience participation sitcom ''[[Terry and Julian]]'' with [[Lee Simpson]], again for Channel 4. His next series was the BBC's studio-based ''[[All Rise for Julian Clary]]'' in 1996, in which he played a judge in a mock courtroom setting.{{cite web|title=The Theatre Workshop: Julian Clary|url=http://www.thetheatreworkshop.com/julian-clary/|website=www.thetheatreworkshop.com|accessdate=13 November 2015}} In 1992, he played a cameo guest star part in the BBC drama, ''[[Virtual Murder (TV series)|Virtual Murder]]''. In his episode, "A Dream of Dracula", he played an undertaker, alongside other guest stars including [[Alfred Marks]], [[Jill Gascoine]], [[Ronald Fraser (actor)|Ronald Fraser]] and [[Peggy Mount]]. He also appeared in an episode of the improvisational comedy show ''[[Whose Line Is It Anyway? (UK TV series)|Whose Line Is It Anyway?]]'' In 1993, he made an infamous appearance at the [[British Comedy Awards]] where he made a joke comparing the set to [[Hampstead Heath]] (a famed London [[cruising for sex|cruising area]] for gay men) and stated that he had just been [[fisting]] the then-[[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] [[Norman Lamont]].{{youtube|iAU7pATH5_M|Julian Clary – Norman Lamont}} Although the joke was met with uproarious laughter from the audience, he was criticised in some newspapers, including the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' and ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'', who launched an unsuccessful campaign to have him banned from television.{{cite news|last1=Roberts|first1=Scott|title=Julian Clary: No regrets over my infamous joke about Norman Lamont|url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2014/10/07/julian-clary-no-regrets-over-my-infamous-joke-about-norman-lamont/|accessdate=14 November 2015|work=Pink News|date=7 October 2014}} From 1998 to 2001, he hosted three series of the Sky TV show ''[[Prickly Heat (game show)|Prickly Heat]]'', the first two series with [[Davina McCall]], the last one with [[Denise van Outen]].{{cite web|title=Van Outen joins Clary for second run of Prickly Heat|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/van-outen-joins-clary-for-second-run-of-prickly-heat/1213716.article|website=www.broadcastnow.co.uk|accessdate=14 November 2015}} Additionally, from 1999 to 2002 he was the face of [[Daz (detergent)|Daz]] laundry detergent, taking over from [[Shane Richie]], [[Michael Barrymore]] and [[Danny Baker]]. He is a recurring performer and one of the most popular performers in the [[ITV Panto]]s. He played 'The 1st Henchman' & 'Tim' in 1998's ''Jack and The Beanstalk''; 'The Good Fairy' in 2000's ''Cinderella''; 'The Genie of the Lamp' in 2000's ''Aladdin''; and, possibly his most favourite character, 'Chris the Cat' in 2002's ''Dick Whittington''.{{cite web|title=Television Pantomimes|url=http://www.its-behind-you.com/tvpanto.html|website=www.its-behind-you.com|accessdate=14 November 2015}} In 1999, he became a team captain on the quiz show ''[[It's Only TV...but I Like It]]'' {{cite news|last1=Lane|first1=Harriet|title=Behind you? Oh, no it's not|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2002/dec/08/features.review17|accessdate=14 November 2015|work=The Observer|date=8 December 2002}} along with [[Phill Jupitus]] and [[Jonathan Ross (television presenter)|Jonathan Ross]]. In 2003, he presented the first series of the Japanese TV clip show, ''[[Sushi TV]]'' for [[Challenge (TV channel)|Challenge]]. In 2004, he took part in the [[BBC]] series ''[[Strictly Come Dancing]]'', finishing third with his partner [[Erin Boag]]. In 2005, he hosted ''Come and Have A Go'' for the [[National Lottery (United Kingdom)|National Lottery]].{{cite web|title=National Lottery Come and Have a Go...|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2005/03_march/14/lottery.shtml|website=www.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 November 2015}} On 1 February 2006, he appeared on the [[BBC]] programme ''[[Who Do You Think You Are? (UK TV series)|Who Do You Think You Are?]]'', a [[genealogy]] series which traced his [[ancestor]]s to a World War I [[flight engineer]] and German immigrants among both his mother's and father's forebears.{{cite web|title=Who Do You Think You Are?: Julian Clary|url=http://www.whodoyouthinkyouaremagazine.com/episode/julian-clary|website=www.whodoyouthinkyouaremagazine.co.uk|accessdate=14 November 2015}} In May 2006, and again in April 2008, he hosted an episode of the topical quiz show ''[[Have I Got News for You]]''. In September 2006, he returned to primetime TV as presenter and judge on Channel 5's brand new celebrity performance programme ''[[The All Star Talent Show]]''. He was joined by two guest judges every week to assess celebrity performances and co-presented with [[Myleene Klass]] and [[Andi Peters]]. He also narrated the Channel 5 children's series ''[[The Little Princess (animated series)|The Little Princess]]'' with [[Jane Horrocks]].{{cite web|title=About Julian Clary|url=http://www.julianclary.co.uk/aboutjulianclary.html|website=www.julianclary.co.uk|accessdate=14 November 2015}} In November 2006, he joined the panel of ''[[QI]]'',{{cite news|last1=Blake|first1=Elissa|title=Julian Clary: The cutting-edge riposte|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/comedy/julian-clary-the-cuttingedge-riposte-20140410-36e69.html|accessdate=14 November 2015|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=12 April 2014}} a [[panel game]]/comedy show hosted by [[Stephen Fry]] and also appeared on an episode of ''[[The New Paul O'Grady Show]]''. In 2007, he made a cameo appearance in the Australian soap opera, ''[[Neighbours]]'', in scenes filmed in London with [[Natalie Bassingthwaighte]].{{cite web|last1=Donaldson|first1=Brian|title=5 things you might not know about Julian Clary|url=https://www.list.co.uk/article/45782-5-things-you-might-not-know-about-julian-clary/|website=www.list.co.uk|publisher=The List|accessdate=14 November 2015}} From 20 March 2007, Clary presented a brand-new show for the [[BBC]] called ''The Underdog Show''. Celebrities and children were paired up with rescue dogs. They then commenced training and competed against each other in obedience and agility trials in a live arena. The show ran until 26 April 2007.{{cite web|title=The Underdog Show: About the show|url=http://www.bbcattic.org/underdogshow/about/index.shtml|website=www.bbcattic.org|publisher=BBC|accessdate=14 November 2015}} He also appeared on television regularly in 2008, starting in January when he was drafted in as a relief presenter for ''[[This Morning (TV programme)|This Morning]]'', co-presenting alongside [[Fern Britton]] and [[Ruth Langsford]] during [[Phillip Schofield]]'s absence. In April, he once again fronted the [[BBC One]] series ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'', and he filmed an episode of ''[[Bargain Hunt|Celebrity Bargain Hunt]]'' in May. He was also a short-notice guest on ''[[The Paul O'Grady Show]]'' in October 2008, after [[Peter Andre]] and [[Katie Price]] couldn't appear (Clary and O'Grady are friends and neighbours).{{cite news|last1=Jackson|first1=Tina|title=My family values: Julian Clary|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2010/jul/24/julian-clary-family-values|accessdate=14 November 2015|work=The Guardian|date=24 July 2010}} In 2012, Clary was one of the contestants in [[Celebrity Big Brother 10]] and went on to win the series. In 2013, he was a judge on the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] entertainment series ''[[Your Face Sounds Familiar (UK TV series)|Your Face Sounds Familiar]]'', alongside [[Emma Bunton]]. In March 2015, it was announced that Clary would take part in ITV's ''[[Give a Pet a Home]]'' show which works alongside the [[RSPCA]] in Birmingham.{{cite web|title=Give a Pet a Home on ITV|url=http://www.itv.com/giveapetahome/julian-clary|website=www.itv.com|accessdate=14 November 2015}} The series began airing on 15 April 2015 for six episodes. From 1 August 2015, Clary presented ''Nature Nuts with Julian Clary'', a new three-part nature show for [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]].{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.itv.com/presscentre/ep1week32/nature-nuts-julian-clary |title=Nature Nuts with Julian Clary Episode 1 |website=Itv.com |date=2 August 2015 |accessdate=14 February 2016}} ===Theatre=== Clary played [[Leigh Bowery]] in the [[West End theatre|West End of London]] musical ''[[Taboo (musical)|Taboo]]'' in 2002. He also took part in the touring production in 2004. In Spring 2007, Clary did a theatre tour of the UK with his show ''An Evening with... Julian Clary''. From 2 October 2007, he played the much coveted role of '[[Emcee]]', in [[Rufus Norris]]'s [[Olivier Award]]-winning production of ''[[Cabaret (musical)|Cabaret]]'', which was in its second year in the West End. Clary was with the show until 19 April 2008. The following year he took part in the ''[[Strictly Come Dancing (series 2)|Strictly Come Dancing]]'' Tour in January and February 2009. He was partnered with [[Lilia Kopylova]]. Clary starred as Michael in ''Le Grand Mort'', a play written specifically for him by playwright Stephen Clark (prior to his death in 2016), opposite James Nelson-Joyce as Tim from 20 September to 28 appeared in the film ''[[Carry On Columbus]]'' (1992),{{cite web|title=Carry On Columbus: cast list|url=https://film.list.co.uk/listings/carry-on/|website=www.film.list.co.uk|accessdate=14 November 2015}} an unsuccessful attempt to revive the "[[Carry On films|Carry On]]" series of films. It was widely panned by critics, but was more financially profitable than the two other Columbus films released the same year: ''[[1492: Conquest of Paradise]]'' and ''[[Christopher Columbus: The Discovery]]''. Clary returned to film in 2001 in the film ''The Baby Juice Express'' {{cite web|title=British Board of Film Classification: Baby Juice Express|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/baby-juice-express-2001|website=www.bbfc.co.uk|accessdate=14 November 2015}} which starred [[Lisa Faulkner]], [[Samantha Womack]], [[Ruth Jones]] and [[David Seaman]], about a prisoner who is desperate to find some way of conceiving with his wife whilst he is in prison, but the sperm ends up getting hijacked. It was released on DVD in 2004. ===Radio=== Clary appeared on ''The Big Fun Show'' in 1988.{{cite web|title=The Big Fun Show|url=http://www.radiolistings.co.uk/programmes/b/bi/big_fun_show__the.html|website=www.radiolistings.co.uk|accessdate=14 November 2015}} In 1992 Clary hosted a radio show for the BBC called ''Intimate Contact'', the premise of which was for him to act as a genial 'Mr Fix-it' for a wide range of 'punter' problems. Clary attempted to solve these issues over the telephone, with the assistance of roving reporter "Hugh Jelly" (actor [[Philip Herbert (actor)|Philip Herbert]]). It originally aired on [[BBC Radio 1]] for two series; the pilot and 6-part first series have since been repeated on [[BBC Radio 7]] a number of times.{{cite web|title=Intimate Contact with Julian Clary|url=http://www.tvcream.co.uk/?p=5988|website=www.tvcream.co.uk|accessdate=14 November 2015}}{{cite web|title=BBC Radio 7: Intimate Contact|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00ffkl6|website=www.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 November 2015}} He has also often been a guest on ''[[Just a Minute]]'', the [[BBC Radio 4]] comedy show. ===Writing=== Clary has released two large format comedy books: ''My Life With Fanny The Wonder Dog'' (1989) and ''How To Be A Man'' (1992). Between 2005 and 2008, Clary wrote a fortnightly column for the ''[[New Statesman]]'' magazine. He has also published an autobiography, ''A Young Man's Passage'', which covers his life and career up to the 1993 "Norman Lamont incident" at the British Comedy Awards (see above). In 2007, Clary released his first novel, ''Murder Most Fab'', published by [[Ebury Press]]. His second novel, ''Devil in Disguise'', was published in 2009. His first book for children, ''The Bolds'', was published by Andersen Press in 2015.{{cite web|title=Julian Clary explains his inspiration behind The Bolds|url=http://www.countryandtownhouse.co.uk/culture/julian-clary-explains-his-inspiration-behind-the-bolds/|website=www.countryandtownhouse.co.uk|publisher=County and Town House}} A sequel, ''The ===Music=== Clary often performs comical renditions of musical numbers in his stage and television appearances, ranging from old classics to original material. He released a music single in 1988 (credited as the Joan Collins Fan Club), a humorous rendition of "[[Leader of the Pack]]", which he often performed in his stage and television appearances at the time. The single was produced by Rupert Hine and reached no. 60 in the UK Singles Chart.{{cite web|url=http://www.chartstats.com/artistinfo.php?id=5168 |title=Chart Stats.com (Joan Collins Fan Club) |publisher=Archive.is |date= |accessdate=7 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120722040240/http://www.chartstats.com/artistinfo.php?id=5168 |archivedate=22 July 2012 |df=dmy }} Another single, "[[Wand'rin' Star|Wandrin' Star]]", was released in 1990. The single was backed with the self-penned track "Uncanny and Unnatural". ==Personal life== He is married to Ian Mackley. The pair have been a couple since 2005 and were married on 19 November 2016.{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/JulianClary/status/800450154461536256|title=Julian Clary on Twitter|newspaper=Twitter|access-date=20 November 2016}} They live in [[Aldington, Kent]], at [[Goldenhurst Farm]], a 17th-century manor house once owned by [[Noël Coward]].{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/gardening/8663935/Celebrity-Gardeners-Julian-Clarys-garden.html|title=Celebrity Gardeners: Julian Clary's garden|date=29 July 2011|publisher=Telegraph|author=|accessdate=14 February 2016}} On 7 September 2005, University of London's Goldsmiths College made Clary an [[Honorary title (academic)|Honorary Fellow]].{{cite web |url=http://www.gold.ac.uk/honorary-appointments/HFDMay2012.pdf| title=The Roll of Honorary Fellows Goldsmiths College, University of London}}{{dead link|date=June 2014}} In July 2014, University of East Anglia awarded Clary an honorary [[Doctor of Civil Law]].{{cite web|author=Rosie Vare |url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/home/photo_gallery_comedian_julian_clary_among_those_receiving_degrees_from_university_of_east_anglia_1_3695709 |title=Photo gallery: Comedian Julian Clary among those receiving degrees from University of East Anglia – Home – Eastern Daily Press |website=Edp24.co.uk |date= |accessdate=14 February 2016}} ==Stand-up VHS and DVD== {| class="wikitable" |- !
